Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Click Brain Analysis Package for Neurological Disorders
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, "Click Brain", is a translational Clinical Decision Support (CDS) that applies software visualization techniques to create a baseline or "fingerprint" of brain MRIs, with particular application for children with suspected developmental disorders, adults with suspected MS, or others with disorders that exhibit brain changes.

One in twenty children in the United States has some form of developmental delay or disorder. Many of these children remain undiagnosed until their symptoms are evident. The delayed diagnosis decreases their chances of overcoming their disabilities and precludes early intervention, which results in large increases in cost of care for these patients over their lifetime. Early MRI imaging of the brain provides a path towards timely diagnosis. However, diagnosis of these disorders via visual inspection of images - the current standard of care - is difficult and time consuming, and may miss subtle but crucial brain changes. Furthermore, diagnosis often requires a highly specialized and experienced pediatric neuroradiologist, a skill not always present in many hospitals. There are no clinical decision support tools to quantitatively evaluate changes in the brain to increase efficiency of interpretation, facilitate uniform interpretation regardless of radiologist experience level and enable earlier diagnosis and monitoring therapeutic interventions. This project's technology, "Click Brain", provides a diagnostic "fingerprint" for neurological disorders such as microcephaly, multiple sclerosis, and traumatic brain injury. It is more efficient (quicker and earlier diagnosis) with higher reproducibility than current qualitative visual examination of the images.

Click Brain is automated, quantitative Clinical Decision Support software that can assess clinically relevant parameters such as: head circumference, total white matter volume, total gray matter volume, ventricular cerebrospinal fluid volume and shape of subcortical structures. Click Brain can also significantly impact patient care by 1) increasing efficiency of interpretation and reporting, 2) promoting more uniform interpretation independent of radiologist experience level, 3) enabling earlier diagnosis, 4) providing data for quantitative longitudinal studies for treatment monitoring, and 5) reducing the impact and cost of developmental disorders. For the customer discovery phase of the I-Corps program, the team will primarily target the following potential customers: Radiologists/neurologists/neurosurgeons to understand how the software could have most impact in terms of disorders and output measurements, and to determine the best way to integrate the software into clinician workflow; Hospital administrators to optimize the team's commercialization strategy; Medical schools to understand the potential market in medical student education; and Pharmaceutical company project managers to determine how Click Brain can help with drug trials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developmental disorders affect as many as 13.87% of children according to the Center for Disease Control  (https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/developmentaldisabilities/features/birthdefects-dd-keyfindings.html). Many of these children remain undiagnosed until their symptoms are evident. The delayed diagnosis decreases children’s chances of overcoming their disabilities and precludes early intervention, which results in large increases in cost of care for these patients over their lifetime. From our I-Corps investigations, we found that pediatric neuroradiologists and clinicians are highly interested in pediatric brain MRI quantitation software to characterize various neurodevelopmental disorders. Our software, Click Brain, will provide this much needed information to clinicians.

During the I-Corps training and with the follow up interviews after the training period, we interviewed approximately 350 opinion leaders in the field, including clinicians working with imaging, radiologists, hospital administrators, representatives of companies in the medical imaging space and policy makers. We talked to medical imaging specialists in several countries including big and small cities and territories in the United States, Canada, Denmark, Germany, Switzerland, Japan, Singapore and South Korea. We also had phone or in person interviews with medical imaging specialists in Italy, Argentina, Mexico, Colombia, Somaliland, Rwanda, Sri Lanka and India.

The principal objective of all these interviews performed through I-Corps is to determine a go/no go decision for Click Brain. We also wanted to define a potential commercialization strategy for Click Brain that would lead to a profitable and sustainable business through clarifying our customer segments as well as identifying potential partners and competitors. From our interviews, it is clear that there is demand for Click Brain type analyses as well as a viable business model to deliver our software as tested through iterating our business model canvas. We found that our first adopters would be pediatric radiologists and neurosurgeons at research hospitals, in countries where MRI are readily available. Many of these interviewees identified Click Brain as a ‘must have’. Clinicians in other specialities varied quite a bit in whether or not they thought Click Brain would be useful to their work, and fell anywhere in the range from ‘must have’ to ‘not interested’. Clinicians at smaller hospitals were typically less enthusiastic for Click Brain, though this also varied quite a bit depending on who we talked to. Finally, while we hypothesized that a software like Click Brain would help ease the chronic shortage of radiologists in many developing countries, the reduced availability of good quality scanners precluded the use of advanced image processing techniques. We are in the process of writing up these findings and others as a journal review on ‘current state of medical imaging in the clinic’. Our I-Corps interviews also allowed us to identify several potential partners and to determine a part toward viability. We recently formed a new startup to commercialize Click Brain – Voxel Healthcare LLC, formerly Advanced Medical Systems LLC - that has recently been awarded an STTR grant from NSF.

Click Brain will participate and be one of the leaders in revolutionizing clinical practice in pediatric medical imaging, by moving from a qualitative to a quantitative model of imaging.  A similar revolution is slowly beginning to take place in the adult space, and Click Brain and its future extensions will help lead the way in pediatrics.
